choices.text: Hypoxic death of cells within the central nervous system
Denatures structural proteins & enzymes and blocks the proteolysis of the dead cells
Microscopically there is a structure less collection of fragmented cells and amorphous granular debris enclosed within a distinctive inflammatory border
Complexes of antigens and antibodies are deposited in the walls of arteries

questions.solution:
• COAGULATIVE NECROSIS:
    • A form of necrosis in which the architecture of dead tissue is preserved for a span of at least some days.
    • The affected tissue has a firm texture.
    • The injury denatures structural proteins & enzymes and so blocks the proteolysis of the dead cells. (Choice B)
    • Intensely eosinophilic cells with indistinct or reddish nuclei may persist for days or weeks.
    • The necrotic cells are broken down by the action of lysosomal enzymes derived from infiltrating leukocytes, which remove the debris of the dead cells by phagocytosis.
    • Ischemia caused by obstruction in a vessel may lead to coagulative necrosis of the supplied tissue in all organs except the brain.
    • A localized area of coagulative necrosis is called an infarct.
  • FIBRINOID NECROSIS:
    • Vascular damage seen in immune reactions involving blood vessels.
    • complexes of antigens and antibodies are deposited in the walls of arteries.(Choice D)
    • Deposits of these immune complexes, together with plasma proteins that has leaked out of vessels, show a bright pink and amorphous appearance.
  • LIQUEFACTIVE NECROSIS:
    • Digestion of the dead cells, resulting in transformation of the tissue into a viscous liquid.
    • Hypoxic death of cells within the central nervous system (CNS). (Choice A)
  • CASEOUS NECROSIS:
    • Foci of Tuberculous infection
    • The necrotic area appears as a structureless collection of fragmented or lysed cells and amorphous granular debris enclosed within a distinctive inflammatory border (Choice C); this appearance is characteristic of a focus of inflammation known as a granuloma.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: A form of necrosis in which the architecture of dead tissue is preserved for a span of at least some days.

questions.text: Choose an correct statement about Pyroptosis?
questions.solution:
PYROPTOSIS:

  • It is a form of apoptosis that is accompanied by the release of the fever-inducing cytokine IL-1 (pyro refers to fever). (Choice A)
  • Microbial products that enter infected cells are recognized by cytoplasmic innate immune receptors and can activate the multiprotein complex called the inflammasome.
  • The function of the inflammasome is to activate CASPASE-1 (ALSO KNOWN AS INTERLEUKIN-1 Β- CONVERTING ENZYME), which cleaves a precursor form of interleukin-1 (IL-1) and releases its biologically active form.
  • IL-1 is a mediator of many aspects of inflammation, including leukocyte recruitment and fever.
  • Caspase-1 and the closely related caspases-4 and -5 also induce death of the cells. Unlike classical apoptosis, this pathway of cell death is characterized by release of inflammatory mediators.
  • Pyroptosis :- some microbes cause the death of infected cells trigger local inflammation.

NECROPTOSIS:

  • The rest of the choices B, C, D are seen in necroptosis.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Pyroptosis is a form of programmed cell death associated with inflammation, triggered by microbial infections or danger signals. It is mediated by the activation of inflammasomes, leading to the cleavage of gasdermin-D by caspase-1 or caspase-11/4/5, which forms pores in the cell membrane. This results in cell lysis, release of pro-inflammatory cytokines like IL-1β and IL-18, and an immune response to eliminate pathogens.

choices.text: Part of nerve attached to cell body in a nerve that is cut peripherally
Cell body that is not attached to the nerve that is cut
Part of nerve not attached to cell body
Cell body that is attached to the nerve that is cut

questions.solution:
Wallerian degeneration refers to degeneration of axons after disruption of nerve fibers.

  • It is the standard response to peripheral nerve injury.
  • It is seen when a nerve fibre is cut which results in the degeneration of part of the axon distal to the injury.
  • Portions of axons that are distal to the point of transection are disconnected from the cell bodies (perikarya)
  • and degenerate. Within a day of injury, the distal axons begin to fragment, and the associated myelin sheaths unravel (Fig. 27.3) and disintegrate into spherical structures (myelin ovoids). Macrophages are recruited and participate in the removal of axonal and myelin debris
  • Wallerian degeneration is seen in part of nerve not attached to cell body.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Wallerian degeneration is the process of axonal degeneration that occurs distal to the site of injury in a neuron. Following axonal damage, the distal segment undergoes breakdown of the axon and myelin, while Schwann cells and macrophages clear debris, facilitating eventual regeneration in peripheral nerves.

choices.text: Altered differentiation pathway of tissue stem cells

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of pathological atrophy?
questions.solution:
Atrophy: Is a reduction in the size of an organ or tissue due to a decrease in cell size and number.

  • Atrophy can be physiologic or pathologic.
  • PHYSIOLOGIC ATROPHY: Is common during normal development.
    • Notochord and thyroglossal duct, undergo atrophy during fetal development.
    • The decrease in the size of the uterus after parturition is another form of physiologic atrophy.
  • PATHOLOGIC ATROPHY:
    • DECREASED WORKLOAD (DISUSE ATROPHY)- The initial decrease in cell size is reversible once activity is resumed. With more prolonged disuse, skeletal muscle fibres decrease in number (due to apoptosis) as well as in size; muscle atrophy can be accompanied by increased bone resorption, leading to osteoporosis of disuse.
    • LOSS OF INNERVATION (DENERVATION ATROPHY)- Damage to the nervesleads to atrophy of the muscle fibres supplied by those nerves. (Choice B)
    • DIMINISHED BLOOD SUPPLY- A gradual decrease in blood supply (chronic ischemia) (Choice C) to a tissue as a result of slowly developing arterial occlusive disease results in tissue atrophy. In late adult life, the brain may undergo progressive atrophy, mainly because of reduced blood supply as a result of atherosclerosis. This is called senile atrophy.
    • INADEQUATE NUTRITION- Profound protein-calorie malnutrition (marasmus) is associated with the utilization of skeletal muscle proteins as a source of energy after other reserves such as adipose stores have been depleted. This results in marked muscle wasting (cachexia). (Choice D)
    • LOSS OF ENDOCRINE STIMULATION- For example, The loss of estrogen stimulation after menopause results in atrophy of the endometrium, vaginal epithelium, and breast.
    • PRESSURE- Tissue compression for any length of time can cause atrophy. An enlarging benign tumor can cause atrophy in the surrounding uninvolved tissues.

questions.text: Which of the following is a central organ in apoptosis?
questions.solution:
Mitochondria is a central component of apoptosis (programmed cell death), which is regularly used to rid the body of cells that are no longer useful or properly function.

  • Apoptosis is an active process regulated by genes and involves RNA and protein synthesis.
  • Two distinct pathways converge on caspase activation:
    • The mitochondrial pathway
    • The death receptor pathway

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Mitochondria is a central component of apoptosis (programmed cell death), which is regularly used to rid the body of cells that are no longer useful or properly function.

choices.text: Calcifications in interstitial tissues of the stomach

questions.text: Psammoma bodies belong to which type of pathologic form of calcification?
questions.solution:
• Dystrophic calcification: Deposition of calcium at sites of cell injury and necrosis
  • Metastatic calcification: Deposition of calcium in normal tissues, caused by hypercalcemia (usually a consequence of parathyroid hormone excess)

Common causes:

  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Chronic renal failure
  • Parathyroid adenomas
  • Paraneoplastic syndrome
  • Vitamin D intoxication
  • Metastatic cancer to the bone

DYSTROPHIC CALCIFICATION:

  • Calcium salts have a basophilic, amorphous granular, sometimes clumped appearance.
  • Intracellular, extracellular, or in both.
  • The progressive acquisition of outer layers of calcification may create lamellated configurations, called psammoma bodies because of their resemblance to grains of sand. Some types of papillary cancers (e.g., thyroid) are apt to develop PSAMMOMA BODIES.

Histological Features:

  • Small, round, eosinophilic structures
  • Concentric, laminated rings resembling a "whorled" appearance
  • Basophilic on H&E staining due to calcium deposits

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Psammoma bodies are concentric, lamellated, calcified structures seen microscopically in various benign and malignant conditions. These are formed by dystrophic calcification around necrotic cells or cellular debris.

Mnemonic for conditions: PSaMMoma

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma
  • Serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary
  • Meningioma
  • Mesothelioma

questions.text: A 43 years old woman's histopathology finding of cholecystectomy specimen is given in the following image. She had complained about intermittent pain below the right costal margin and vomiting on & off. Identify the cells (arrow).
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the above case is CHOLESTEROLOSIS.

  • This refers to the focal accumulations of cholesterol-laden macrophages(FOAM CELLS) in the lamina propria of the gallbladder. (Choice D)
  • Cholesterolosis is often associated with cholesterol gallstones.
  • The gross pathology :- linear yellow streaks are seen in the prominences of the mucosal ridges, surrounded by congested mucosa ("STRAWBERRY GALLBLADDER") Sometimes one or more of the deposits grow larger and protrude into the lumen, in which case they are referred to as cholesterol polyps.
  • Microscopically :- collections of lipid-filled foamy cells are present in the tips of the villi. Inflammatory changes are usually insignificant, unless the cholesterosis is accompanied by stones in the cystic duct.

The other cells from choices A, B, C are not present in the above image of Cholesterolosis.

Gall bladder mucosa is lined by columnar lining, so squamous cells are not seen usually. (Choice A)

Serosa of gall bladder shows fat cells (adipocytes) which is not been shown in the image.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Cholesterosis is the accumulation of cholesterol esters and foam cells (lipid-laden macrophages) within the lamina propria of the gallbladder, leading to the characteristic appearance of "strawberry gallbladder."

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common exogenous pigment?
questions.solution:
EXOGENOUS PIGMENTS:

  • The most common exogenous pigment is carbon (coal dust), a ubiquitous air pollutant in urban areas.
  • When inhaled, it is picked up by macrophages within the alveoli and then transported through lymphatic channels to lymph nodes in the tracheobronchial region.
  • Accumulations of this pigment blacken the tissues of the lungs (anthracosis) and the involved lymph nodes.
  • Tattooing is a form of localized, exogenous pigmentation of the skin.

ENDOGENOUS PIGMENTS:

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Exogenous pigments are substances introduced into the body from external sources, resulting in discoloration of tissues. These pigments are not synthesized within the body.

questions.text: A 67 years old man dies 24 hours after the onset of substernal chest pain radiating down his left arm, ulnar aspect to his fingerprints. Which of the following morphological myocardial findings indicates irreversible injury?
questions.solution:
Irreversible Cell Injury

Irreversible cell injury refers to cellular damage that exceeds the threshold for repair, leading to permanent loss of function and cell death.

Mechanisms of Irreversible Cell Injury:

  1. Severe Membrane Damage:
    • Loss of selective permeability.
    • Leakage of cellular contents and influx of calcium.
  2. Mitochondrial Dysfunction:
    • Inability to produce ATP due to extensive mitochondrial damage.
    • Release of pro-apoptotic factors (e.g., cytochrome c).
  3. Lysosomal Rupture:
    • Release of hydrolytic enzymes leading to autolysis.
  4. DNA Damage:
    • Extensive damage that cannot be repaired, triggering apoptosis.

Morphological Changes:

  1. Microscopic Features:
    • Nuclear Changes:
      • Pyknosis: Condensation of nuclear chromatin.
      • Karyorrhexis: Fragmentation of the nucleus.
      • Karyolysis: Dissolution of the nucleus.
    • Loss of cytoplasmic and organelle integrity.
  2. Ultrastructural Changes:
    • Ruptured plasma membrane.
    • Swelling and rupture of mitochondria.
    • Detachment of ribosomes from the rough endoplasmic reticulum.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Irreversible cell injury refers to cellular damage that exceeds the threshold for repair, leading to permanent loss of function and cell death.

questions.text: Which of the following defective gene product is seen in the patients with werner syndrome?
questions.solution:
WERNER SYNDROME:

  • Premature aging
  • The defective gene product is a DNA helicase, a protein involved in DNA replication and repair and other functions requiring DNA unwinding.
  • A defect in this enzyme causes rapid accumulation of chromosomal damage that may mimic some aspects of the injury that normally accumulates during cellular aging.
  • Cellular aging:
    • A progressive decline in cellular function and viability caused by genetic abnormalities.
    • the accumulation of cellular and molecular damage due to the effects of exposure to exogenous influences.
    • Mechanisms that cause cellular aging:-
      • DNA damage
      • Cellular senescence
      • Defective protein homeostasis
      • Dysregulated nutrient sensing
    • DNA Polymerase (choice A) mutation causes many conditions like X-linked intellectual disability (XLID), Cancers (e.g colorectal and endometrial tumors).
    • RNA Polymerase (choice D) mutation causes various diseases such as ribosomopathies, leukemia and solid tumors.
    • DNA ligase (choice C) defect can cause a number of conditions as DNA ligase IV syndrome, Fanconi anemia.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Werner syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by premature aging (progeria) and an increased risk of cancer and metabolic diseases. It is also known as "adult progeria."

Reference: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.bbagrm.2012.10.014 a

questions.text: Enzyme responsible for respiratory burst is?
questions.solution:
Reactive Oxygen Species.

ROS are produced by the rapid assembly and activation of a multicomponent oxidase, NADPH oxidase (also called phagocyte oxidase), which oxidizes reduced nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH) and, in the process, reduces oxygen to superoxide anion.

In neutrophils, this oxidative reaction is triggered by activating signals accompanying phagocytosis and is called the RESPIRATORY BURST.

The other choices are not seem to be useful in respiratory burst.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: ROS are produced by the rapid assembly and activation of a multicomponent oxidase, NADPH oxidase (also called phagocyte oxidase), which oxidizes reduced nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH) and, in the process, reduces oxygen to superoxide anion.
